-- Used in Main Activity --
CNAF Flight Surgeon Naval Air Forces Flight Surgeon By selecting \"Start\" and continuing the use of this application you are acknowledging that you understand the requirements of the Privacy Act of 1974 and take full responsilbility for compliance with the requirements therein. This app is not endorsed by the US Navy. Copyright Â© 2018 Luke Griswold.
-- Used in Home Activity--
Physiolgical Event (PE) Definitions Restart View CPG A Physiological Event is a subset of PHYSEPs where the following two criteria are met:\n1. Aircrew or maintainer experiences physiologic symptoms\n2. Due to a known or suspected aircraft or aircrew systems malfunction. Symptomology Begin PE Protocol Initial Actions -If possible, meet the aircrew at the flight line.\n- Before beginning tests/exam, have the Part C form ready as well as the ability to administer a full neurological exam (see action bar or Appendix 5A) \n\n- Labs: CBC, UA, BMP, SRS (Serum Respository Sample is a VOLUNTARY DRAW. Order as an HIV sample for future analysis of contaminants). \n\n- Rad-57 analysis while on RA. \n\n- Comprehensive physical exam (including full neuro evaluation). \n\n- 72 hour history. Does Rad-57 Show: 1. SpO₂ > 95% on RA? \n\n2. SpCO < 10%? Yes to both No to either
PE Symptomology Physiologic symptoms refer to any of the following: \n\ni) One or more somatic disturbances occurring during flight, after flight, or experienced relative to maintenance requiring the operation of the aircraft. \n\nii) The symptoms are distracting to the safe operation of the aircraft or degrade the mission capability of the air or maintenance crew. \n\niii) Manifestations of any of the following symptoms: \n- Anxiousness / nervousness \n- Changes in thought process** \n- Clumsiness \n- Difficulty breathing \n- Difficulty communicating** \n- Disorientation \n- Dizziness \n- Fatigue or drowsiness \n- Feeling slowed or "off" \n- Feeling euphoric or elated \n- Headache \n- Light headedness \n- Memory difficulties** \n- Nausea \n- Pain anywhere, especially in joints \n- Personality changes** \n- Skin rashes \n- Vertigo \n- Vision changes or complaints \n- Symptoms that suggest DCS I / II or AGE (DCI) \n\n**May be self-reported or endorsed by a significant other or peer who knows the aviator well enough to report subtle changes in personality or thought process
-- CPG Branch data-- CPG Home Legal Feedback Neuro Clinical Practice Guideline Neuro Exam
-- Chamber Info -- Chamber Resources Known or suspected DCS II / AGE MUST be reviewed with the NAMI UMO PRIOR to discharge! Call NAMI UMO View Chambers

--- Legal and Feedback Strings --- By using this application, you are ackknowledging that you understand the requirements of the Privacy Act of 1974 and take full responsibility for compliance with the requirements therein. Response to a tragedy inherently requires Privacy Act sensitive information. Inadequate password protection on your mobile device or your electronic communication accounts directly places any Privacy Act information associated with this application at risk. \n\nThis application is intended to provide suggestions/guidance for tragedy preparation and response, but cannot guarantee the best solution for the situation you are responding to. Due to the dynamic nature of both Naval Aviation and human interaction, no two tragedy responses will be identical. Your continued use of this application explicitly implies that you will determine what elements of this plan apply to your situation and agree to hold both the development team and all agents of the US government harmless. Privacy Act of 1974
Feedback is essential to improving the quality of the flight surgeon response products. Please provide the following information when emailing feedback (this will auto-populate if you use the "Email feedback" button). \n\n1. Use subject line "CNAF Flight Surgeon app feedback" \n\n2. Name(optional), command, and if you are interested in a response. \n\n3. Module (Mishap Response, PHYSEP, and platform) and screen any issue is found in. A screenshot of any issue you may be reporting is helpful. \n\n4. Feedback \n\nThank you for taking the time to provide feedback! Feedback email address: CNAFCOGuide@gmail.com Email feedback CNAFCOGuide@gmail.com CNAF Flight Surgeon app feedback, version 1.0.0 android App development team, \n\nName: (Optional) \nCommand: \nResponse desired? \nModule: Mishap response / PHYSEP \nScreen: \nIssue: \nRecommendations: \nGeneral comments: \n\nContact information: (Optional)
Conclusion Complete the following to conclude the PE: \n\n1. Flight surgeon must communicate working diagnosis and plan to the aircrew, their command, and medical chain of command (up to TYCOM level). \n\n2. Complete Part C and AHLTA PE template. \n\n3. Aircrew being discharged should have someone (roommate or family) watching them until followup is complete to ensure no recurrence of symptoms or other subtle changes. \n\n4. Aircrew will followup with the Flight Surgeon at 24 and 48hrs after episode or discharge. Update Part C if additional treatment is required. \n\n5. Complete WESS entry as directed by Safety Officer
